turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Red-naped sapsucker.
turn.1: Where does the Red-naped sapsucker nest?
turn.2: (Sphyrapicus nuchalis) nests have been described primarily in trembling aspen ("Populus tremuloides") with decay-softened wood.
turn.3: Why do they choose trembling aspen?
turn.4: Heart-wood decay is reported to infect the roots of most aspens that red-naped sapsuckers choose to excavate for nesting.
turn.5: What else is interesting about their nesting?
turn.6: Red-naped sapsuckers typically excavate their first cavity relatively close to the ground and over subsequent years make progressively higher excavations.
turn.7: Do the excavations get bigger every year?
turn.8: Most (68%) nest trees were live and 75% had broken tops.
turn.9: Do they use any other plants?
turn.10: Western larch (Larix occidentalis) and birch were greatly over utilized compared to their availability.
